oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Various interviews for Crazy - Top 100 Songs of the Century - All Things Considered - 2000-09-04 - NPR
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Excerpt from radio program All Things Considered, broadcast on National Public Radio, regarding Patsy Cline's recording of Crazy as part of the Top 100 Songs of the Century, featuring interviews with Charlie Dick (husband of Cline), Gordon Stoker (Jordanaires), Bob Moore (bass guitar on Crazy), Harold Bradley (brother of Owen Bradley), Kathy Mattea, and Paul Kingsbury (CMHoF), conducted by an unidentified female interviewer.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Test tones -- (01:37) [Unidentified] introduces 1961 hit single Crazy by Patsy Cline, written by Willie Nelson, as one of NPR's top 100 songs of the century -- (02:19) [Unidentified] talks about how Cline's husband Charlie Dick found the song for her -- (02:37) Charlie Dick talks about meeting Willie Nelson, and eventually getting the demo for Crazy from Willie -- (03:15) Dick talks about Cline not liking Willie -- (03:55) Paul Kingsbury talks about Patsy's vocal techniques and versatility, as well as her ability to emulate her emotions through song -- (04:30) [Unidentified] talks about Cline's car accident she had just before recording Crazy -- (04:50) Kingsbury talks about Willie Nelson's innovative songwriting techniques during the 1960's, as well in lyrics -- (05:30) [Unidentified] talks about Owen Bradley's plans for Crazy, which including bring in the Jordanaires on background vocals, Floyd Kramer on piano, Bob Moore on bass guitar, and numerous recording sessions -- (06:43) Gordon Stoker talks about Cline not being impressed when hearing Willie's demo of Crazy, namely because of his iconic phrasing -- Bob Moore and Harold Bradley agree about Willie's off kilter phrasing around the beat of the song -- (07:56) Bradley talks about disagreements between Owen and Cline when recording Crazy -- Stoker talks about Cline singing the best when she was angry with Owen Bradley -- Stoker talks about the Jordanaires appearing on much of Cline's recordings after the success of Crazy -- Bob Moore talks about the tic-tac bass guitar on the recording of Crazy -- (10:00) Stoker talks about Crazy being different from anything being recording at that time, and how great Cline did on the record -- (11:40) [Unidentified] talks about Crazy being recorded over multiple studio sessions, but Cline's vocals only took one take -- (12:18) Kathy Mattea talks about how technology can be bad for catching magical moments in recorded music -- (12:42) [Unidentified] talks about Cline's death in the plane crash -- (14:11) Closing statement
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: National Public Radio (U.S.); All things considered (Radio program); Cline, Patsy, 1932-1963; Bradley, Owen; Bradley, Harold (Guitarist); Dick, Charlie; Stoker, Gordon, 1924-2013; Jordanaires (Musical group); Moore, Bob, 1932-; Mattea, Kathy; Kingsbury, Paul
